conclusion: To determine the maximum width of the incident light beam on AB, consider the critical angle for total internal reflection at the upper surface.
Identify the critical angle as the angle of incidence above which total internal reflection occurs, given by sin(θ_c) = 1/n.
The critical angle θ_c is given by sin(θ_c) = 1/n, where n is the refractive index of the glass.
Determine the angle of incidence at the upper surface related to the angle of refraction at the lower surface.
Since the light is incident vertically on the lower surface, the angle of incidence at the upper surface is the same as the angle of refraction at the lower surface.
Snell's Law states n_1 sin(θ_1) = n_2 sin(θ_2).
Here, n_1 is the refractive index of the glass, and n_2 is the refractive index of air (approximately 1).
Calculate the maximum angle of incidence at the upper surface as the critical angle θ_c, therefore sin(θ_c) = 1/n.
Relate the angle to the geometry: the maximum width of the incident light beam corresponds to the maximum distance from the center O to the point where the light exits the upper surface.
This distance is given by R sin(θ_c).
Calculate the maximum width of the incident light beam on AB as twice this distance, resulting in 2R sin(θ_c).
The maximum width of the incident light beam on AB is 2R sin(θ_c).
